item.title: A new post: Markdown language
item.description:
##Markdown language Cheatsheet:

  • Markdown-Cheatsheet

###Make pluma (fork of gedit2) work with Markdown format:

  • Download markdown.lang from [https://raw.githubusercontent.com/nacho/gtksourceview/master/data/language-specs/markdown.lang], i,e, from Gnome-3 gedit
  • Copy it into MATE directory: $ sudo cp ~/some-dir/markdown.lang /usr/share/gtksourceview-2.0/language-specs //See also [1 https://ubuntu-mate.community/t/adding-syntax-highlighting-to-pluma/56]

BTW it sits here: /usr/share/gtksourceview-3.0/language-specs/markdown.lang so it can be created as symlink: ln -s /usr/share/gtksourceview-3.0/language-specs/markdown.lang /usr/share/gtksourceview-2.0/language-specs/markdown.lang

== ####Just a side note: Is there any program designed for writing a book? in Linux

item.title: Welcome to Jekyll!
item.description:
You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

To add new posts, simply add a file in the _posts directory that follows the convention YYYY-MM-DD-name-of-post.ext and includes the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.
